description: From Middle English peril, from Old French peril, from Latin perÄ«culum. Doublet of periculum.

entries.meaning: A situation of serious and immediate danger.
Something that causes, contains, or presents danger.
examples: the perils of the jungle (animals and insects, weather, etc.)

entries.meaning: (insurance) An event which causes a loss, or the risk of a specific such event.

verbs.description: peril (third-person singular simple present perils, present participle periling or perilling, simple past and past participle periled or perilled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to be in danger; to imperil; to risk. [from 16th c.]
examples: And are we, Mr. President, who stood by our country then, who threw open our coffers, who bared our bosoms, who freely perilled all in that conflict, to be reproached with want of attachment to the Union?
